posts.title: GSoC 2025 Zarr: Introduction
posts.text: Introduction to the Bit-Packing Project of Zarr under NumFOCUS Side Channel Analysis (SCA) has grown into a critical area of research due to its profound implications for both security and privacy. By examining power consumption from electronic devices, attackers can infer sensitive information. SCA contributes to developing stronger cryptographic protocols, more secure hardware designs, and advanced countermeasures. In addition, better protection against side channel attacks safeguards personal data and financial transactions, underscoring the vital need for ongoing investigation in this field. A key challenge in large-scale SCA arises from the massive volume of high-resolution measurements needed for thorough security evaluations. These measurements often captured at 10-bit or 12-bit resolution, with large datasets for each time steps. The SCARR framework (Bosland et al. 2024) introduce a high-performance design patterns, combined with a modern file format Zarr and optimized compression, which can substantially reduce data sizes while accelerating key SCA algorithms. This enable SCA procedures such as Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) and Correlation Power Analysis (CPA) to run significantly faster, often outperforming existing frameworks by a factor of two. Zarrâ€™s design, which allows for on-the-fly compression and efficient random access to large datasets, is ideally suited for SCA research. Integrating specialized bit-packing algorithms into Zarr can further boost performance when handling 10-bit or 12-bit ADC samples, providing both lower storage costs and faster I/O operations. In doing so, the project directly contributes to SCARRâ€™s vision of making side-channel evaluations more scalable and cost-effective, ultimately enabling more comprehensive security testing in SCA research. This Google Summer of Code project aims to create bit-packing compression method optimized for SCA data in the open source library Zarr. By focusing on an approach that caters to 10-bit or 12-bit ADC samples, the project seeks to find any possible compression method that performs between the baseline of uncompressed data, and LZ4 within HDF5. Through efficient compression, the initiative will help researchers spend more time on analysis and less time on I/O, thereby enabling faster experimentation and a deeper exploration of side channel analysis Reference Bosland, Jonah et al. (Mar. 2024). â€œHigh-Performance Design Patterns and File Formats for Side-Channel Analysisâ€. In: IACR Transactions on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems 2024.2, pp. 769â€“794. doi: 10 . 46586 / tches . v2024 . i2 . 769 - 794. url: https ://ojs.ub.rub.de/index.php/TCHES/article/view/11446.

posts.title: GSoC Latex Templete
posts.text: Self made open source Latex Template for GSoC GSoC_latex_templateA custom Latex template for the Google Summer of Code, based on the template originally from University of Amsterdam UvA Informatica Template Artikel by Robert van Wijk Title PageSuitable Title page to include all the personal, organization, mentor, and project information. Work Breakdown Structure GraphUpdated work breakdown structure graph based on the work of Gonzalo Medina Proposal RequirementListed requirements for the proposal based on the webpage of Writing a proposal by GSoC Guide and Proposal Template by NumFOCUS
